repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
Adding initial support for `completionItem/resolve` requests. 

Initially mentioned in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/13199

After completion, some sources can supply additional information, like `additionalTextEdits`. For lsps like typescript, they can auto-import the completion item that was just selected.


https://twitter.com/mhartington/status/1333140077510340623


Marking as WIP for now, as there is https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/12874

cc @tjdevries

comment_data.body: if you're interested, you can do `vim.v.completed_item` :)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1110,6 +1114,26 @@ function lsp.buf_notify(bufnr, method, params)
   return resp
 end
 
+
+--@private
+--- Get the details of the completion item
+function lsp._resolve_completion_detail()
+  local bufnr = resolve_bufnr()
+  local completed_item_var = vim.api.nvim_get_vvar('completed_item')

comment_data.body: why do we have to do the filter?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1110,6 +1114,26 @@ function lsp.buf_notify(bufnr, method, params)
   return resp
 end
 
+
+--@private
+--- Get the details of the completion item
+function lsp._resolve_completion_detail()
+  local bufnr = resolve_bufnr()
+  local completed_item_var = vim.api.nvim_get_vvar('completed_item')
+  local item = completed_item_var.user_data.lsp.completion_item
+  local lnum = item.data.line
+  lsp.buf_request(bufnr, 'completionItem/resolve', item, function(err, _, result)
+    if err or not result then return end
+    if result.additionalTextEdits then
+      local edits = vim.tbl_filter(
+        function(x) return x.range.start.line ~= (lnum - 1) end,
+        result.additionalTextEdits
+      )

comment_data.body:
I think this logic came originally from me and somehow made it into nvim-completion. The reason for it was that in my version I did a snippet expansion right after using `item.textEdit.newText`, and if the `additionalTextEdits` affect the current line it would affect the cursor position and mess up the snippet expansion positioning. 

The spec also says this:

```
Additional text edits should be used to change text unrelated to the
	 * current cursor position (for example adding an import statement at the
	 * top of the file if the completion item will insert an unqualified type).
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1110,6 +1114,26 @@ function lsp.buf_notify(bufnr, method, params)
   return resp
 end
 
+
+--@private
+--- Get the details of the completion item
+function lsp._resolve_completion_detail()
+  local bufnr = resolve_bufnr()
+  local completed_item_var = vim.api.nvim_get_vvar('completed_item')
+  local item = completed_item_var.user_data.lsp.completion_item
+  local lnum = item.data.line
+  lsp.buf_request(bufnr, 'completionItem/resolve', item, function(err, _, result)
+    if err or not result then return end
+    if result.additionalTextEdits then
+      local edits = vim.tbl_filter(
+        function(x) return x.range.start.line ~= (lnum - 1) end,
+        result.additionalTextEdits
+      )

comment_data.body:
Why do you delete this namespace?

I think the `_resolve_completion_detail` should work with only `nvim-lsp`'s completed item.

In my knowledge, the LSP clients apply `additionalTextEdits` or snippet extensions on only ` CompleteDone`.

So I think `_on_complete_done` or` _confirm_completed_item` is a better name.

For example, some LSP clients send a `completionItem/resolve` in vim's `CompleteChanged` event to display the document.

However, Currently, this function cannot be called on CompleteChanged because it will apply additionalTextEdits.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1110,6 +1111,28 @@ function lsp.buf_notify(bufnr, method, params)
   return resp
 end
 
+
+--@private
+--- Get the details of the completion item
+function lsp._resolve_completion_detail()
+  local bufnr = resolve_bufnr()
+  local completed_item_var = vim.v.completed_item
+  if
+    completed_item_var and completed_item_var.user_data and completed_item_var.user_data.lsp and
+      completed_item_var.user_data.lsp.completion_item
+   then
+    local item = completed_item_var.user_data.lsp.completion_item
+    lsp.buf_request(bufnr, "completionItem/resolve", item, function(err, _, result)
+      if err or not result then
+        return
+      end
+      if result.additionalTextEdits then
+        util.apply_text_edits(result.additionalTextEdits, bufnr)

@@ -1110,6 +1111,28 @@ function lsp.buf_notify(bufnr, method, params)
   return resp

+      if err or not result then

+      end
+      if result.additionalTextEdits then
+        util.apply_text_edits(result.additionalTextEdits, bufnr)

comment_data.body:
I'm not sure if this path is universally correct.

In my ts-server setup the correct path is `completed_item_var.user_data.lsp.completion_item` (without the "nvim" prop)

comment_data.body: You're probably using completion.nvim, which nest things under a different name space.

comment_regular_data.body:
Won't this be painfully slow for large lists? We are sync requesting for every item in the list.

I think we want to do it _only_ when you select the item, right?

Potentially! Testing this with anything more than a 5 items does get slow. Could use the `CompleteDone` auto cmd and process the result there? And if that's the case, should this live in the realm of a plugin?

I think this is directly in the spec, so implementing here is a good idea. I think we could use something `v:completed_item` and `CompleteDone` to resolve if the completion item came from lsp (which willcontain data in `user_data`)
Makes sense. Should I wait until #12874 or just start go fo it?
Made some more progress. Only question is where would be an appropriate place to setup the AutoCmd for CompleteDone? Right now it's just towards the bottom of lsp.lua, but that is not ideal

You shouldn't wait for my other PR. I will move your changes into it when I get a chance to work on it.

You should make it a buffer local autocmd when the client attaches to a buffer. I don't remember off-hand where the code for that is. That way this ONLY happens for buffers with an LSP.
Could probably use a test. Do you need some assistance on the test? Should at least test that we call complete done when we're done.

Should there be an option for users to opt-out of this? Or how would this interact with [completion-nvim](https://github.com/nvim-lua/completion-nvim) which does something similar already?

Also keep in mind that clients should advertise capabilities for this. From the (upcoming 3.16.0) spec:

> When the item is selected in the user interface then a completionItem/resolve request is sent with the selected completion item as a parameter. The returned completion item should have the documentation property filled in. By default the request can only delay the computation of the detail and documentation properties. Since 3.16.0 the client can signal that it can resolve more properties lazily. This is done using the completionItem#resolveSupport client capability which lists all properties that can be filled in during a completionItem/resolve request. All other properties (usually sortText, filterText, insertText and textEdit) must be provided in the textDocument/completion response and must not be changed during resolve.

@tjdevries regarding test, yeah, could use a hand with that. Also want to make sure Im safely accessing the values in the completion_item

```
local completed_item_var = vim.v.completed_item
local item = completed_item_var.user_data.lsp.completion_item
```
 
I've seen this traversal of `user_data` produce

```
E5108: Error executing lua .../mhartington/bin/nvim/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/lsp.lua:1123: attempt to index field 'user_data' (a nil value)
```



@mfussenegger I had considered that. Another option instead of providing this by default is that the implementation is just public and it would be up to the users to add the autocmd. Similar to how the omnifunc is provided, but users have to add this to their config to enable it.

```
api.nvim_buf_set_option(bufnr, "omnifunc", "v:lua.vim.lsp.omnifunc")
```


As for `completion-nvim` compat, they seem to provide their own implementation of a few lsp internal functions so I don't think this would be an issue. And even so, they could always update their implementation to account for this change.

> As for completion-nvim compat, they seem to provide their own implementation of a few lsp internal functions so I don't think this would be an issue. And even so, they could always update their implementation to account for this change.

I think they'd actually have to override `vim.lsp._resolve_completion_detail` to do nothing. Otherwise applying the `additionalTextEdits` asynchronous could trip up whatever the plugin is doing in their own `CompleteDone` event.

I'd prefer a opt-in to this, but I'm probably biased as I already have a custom `CompleteDone`. I guess as long as this can be disabled it should be fine for plugins.

@mfussenegger that makes sense. I've removed the autocmd and made it something people will need to opt-in to. Again, like the omnifunc, people can register the function like so

```
local on_attach = function(client, bufnr)
  -- ...
  vim.api.nvim_command("autocmd CompleteDone <buffer> lua vim.lsp._resolve_completion_detail()")
  -- ...
end
```

@tjdevries I think all that is left is docs and tests. Then should be good to go.

I wonder if we should provide infrastructure to do this without autocommands.

Perhaps a key in user data could have a function that gets called afterwards.... I'm not sure.

> I wonder if we should provide infrastructure to do this without autocommands.

So I've removed the built in autocmds. People will need to opt-in to getting this functionality to be able to apply edits.
As for a way to do this without autocmds, depending on what people need, there is always `'textDocument/codeAction'` which should help here.

This is something I've spent the last 12 hours looking at, I didn't realise it wasn't implemented yet but I've learnt a lot about the LSP protocol I guess!

One thing that might be worth thinking about is that other editors often resolve this data *before* confirming the completion and display the changes (like "auto import for from bar") in the completion menu so it may be a good idea to wrap this as a two step process where the resolution of the changes from the LSP server and the application of the changes are separate. That way, a completion plugin can request the data before applying it.
resolve support was added as part of https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/27339

title: add support for completionItem/resolve
